Name of the game is multifandom with a splash of everything else under the sun. Recurring themes include Hannibal, LOTR, Marvel, NiF, Star Trek, Star Wars and Supernatural plus whatever phase I'm going through. Also lots of random stuff.

tags: i grant that not everyone catches this
so some people might come from the movie thinking 'US army yay'
but honestly i think the message is pretty clear
title: Captain Marvel isn’t army propaganda
body:
SPOILERS!

No seriously, it isn’t.

I can see how you might think that on first glance - three of the good guys galls either are or used to be US army and there aren’t really any balancing characters for them. But that’s a thin veneer over a very different kind of story.

First of all, there are only three characters of note with US army background. (We’re not counting SHIELD.) All three of them are women and while they are presented in a positive light, their experience within the army isn’t, really. We see both Maria and Carol face and talk about prejudice and misogyny in the army. It’s made explicit. On top of that, we’re faced with the army’s habit of covering things up and how that negatively affects people. Not exactly a very flattering image of the US army, is it - regardless of whether it’s actually the 90s or not.

In addition, all three of the army characters are actually dissociated from the US army one way or the other. Maria no longer seems to be working there (though we don’t get confirmation or explanation) and her attitude towards the Air Force can’t exactly be called endorsing; she deals out some criticism there. Carol on the other hand barely remembers the army and what she does remember is either negatively tinted - read: prejudice towards her - or deals with her personal relationships with the two other women. She also does not care at all about any authority the army might (try to) claim to have.

And then we have Lawson - who could fill the role of the good army authority, except it turns out she’s an alien who’s basically just been using the US army’s resources to develope her own technology. And not even weaponry! No, her explicit goal is to “stop the war” - not by landing a decisive hit but by helping people escape the war. She denounces war - the war - outloud, which pretty clearly separates her from her army association.

And that brings us to the actual plot of this movie.

Namely, the big glaring antimilitaristic message that’s underlying damn near everything.

The whole Kree-Skrull plot is basically a metaphor for US actions in the Middle East. Noble warrior heroes? A culture that venerates soldiers for protecting the homeland/people/way of life by fighting. Diguised enemies working in outer territories? The war’s not at home but somewhere else and the enemy isn’t a typical government-lead army. The indigenous people get mostly ignored, viewed with reserved suspicion? That scene could’ve been from so many war movies depicting conflicts from the last thirty years.

And then it turns out that the terrorists are refugees. Not innocent, not unbloodied - they have been fighting against the Kree. But by all accounts, the Kree are the aggressor with superior forces and an advantage. They’re labeling all Skrulls terrorists and hunting them down no matter the collateral damage - including the destruction of other worlds, other people. The noble warrior heroes are fighting a war that’s neither noble nor heroic.

And that’s where the antimilitaristic, anti-army message drives home. Starforce is Air Force. Carol isn’t actually dissociated from the army after all; she’s in the army. But that army is in the wrong, is commiting atrocities, is lying to her - and when she finds out, she admits she’s been fighting for the wrong cause and does the right thing, taking back her agency in the process.

Captain Marvel is the story of Carol Danvers becoming disillusioned with the army - any army, all armies, it doesn’t matter - and dissociating herself from it.

Captain Marvel is not army propaganda.

blog.name: thisiscomics
blog.title: A Panel A Day (more or less)
blog.description: I probably read too many comics. Here are some highlights. If you like, go give money to the creators.

summary: Here’s a classic I have never read- when the X-Men were 90s-big, I knew it was the first appearance of Rogue, and so a costly...
body:
Here’s a classic I have never read- when the X-Men were 90s-big, I knew it was the first appearance of Rogue, and so a costly back issue, but I didn’t know much about Carol Danvers then, just that Rogue took her powers, and don’t recall anyone focusing on the fact that it’s a fine example of Michael Golden’s amazing skills (I only knew of him as a cover artist, and the first year or so of The ‘Nam. I had never seen superhero interiors from him), because it was all about first appearances and hot artists back then. There’s a hell of a lot more here than that first appearance, and it definitely deserves some sort of classic status.

It’s a funny choice for the True Believers tie ins to the Captain Marvel movie, purely because it has so little Carol in it- we start after Rogue has drained her powers, and much of the plot involves trying to catch Rogue/deal with the Brotherhood of Evil Mutant’s plan to take down the Avengers. While the other Avengers recover from any attack in order to defeat their enemy, Ms Marvel is sidelined. The story had a significant impact on the character, so you can see why it’s been released, but we don’t actually see that here. Still, a damn fine classic for one whole dollar is not something I’m gong to object to.

Carol’s re-appearance in the closing pages is very interesting- it’s quite the challenge to the entire concept of the Avengers, holding them to a higher purpose than just punching bad guys in a no holds barred speech. She also takes them to task for the entirety of a previous story-line where they appear to have been quite accepting of the more than slightly bizarre events that led to this day: Carol was sort of pregnant after being taken to another dimension and came back and ‘gave birth’ to the same person that made her pregnant and took her to said dimension, then went off to stay in the alternate dimension with kidnapper-baby-guy, and, yeah, they were fine with that because love. It’s not a tale I was actually familiar with, thankfully, but it’s clear that Claremont really didn’t approve and uses this annual to take everyone involved to task on it. She may be addressing the superheroes, but it’s safe to assume this was aimed just as much, if not more so, at editorial and the writers of that arc.

(More about this can be read in Carol A Strickland’s essay on Avengers 200 and the aftermath (where it is confirmed that Claremont was not happy with what had been done to Carol since Ms Marvel- with him as writer- was cancelled):

http://carolastrickland.com/comics/msmarvel/ )

As a result, Carol’s words read like a plea to comics in general- ‘Grow. Mature. Stop your patriarchal bullshit and let’s try and act like something better than all that crap.’ It’s pretty impressive stuff, really- the default comics approach, even today, would be to retcon the story somehow, but Claremont deliberately leaves it to stand (although he does make a point of erasing any of the consequences by killing off the Marcus character and having Danvers reassert herself as here, in this reality, with her own plans, which at least gives her some degree of liberation from that ill thought out arc). This means that the actions of the so-called heroes have to be addressed, rather than being recast in a more favourable light.

Claremont makes a point of leaving them to face their faults: the heroes have let down one of their own, and don’t get a free pass. Comics creators let down one of their own, and they need to admit that. The Annual asks them to do better and not repeat those mistakes again.

It’s interesting to see that just as Captain Marvel now leads the charge for female-centred Marvel Studios product (and the ensuing complaints that prospect brings from the entitled and ignorant), she had tried to do the same for comics even before Kelly Sue gave her the Captain title she had long deserved and really put her on the map once more. Looks like it’s time to find those old Claremont Ms Marvels and see what else there is to admire in there.

From Avengers Annual 10, by Chris Claremont, Michael Golden, Armando Gil & Joe Rosen, reprinted in True Believers: Captain Marvel- Betrayed!

She may be addressing the superheroes, but it’s safe to assume this was aimed just as much, if not more so, at editorial and the writers of that arc.

(More about this can be read in Carol A Strickland’s essay on Avengers 200 and the aftermath (where it is confirmed that Claremont was not happy with what had been done to Carol since Ms Marvel- with him as writer- was cancelled):

http://carolastrickland.com/comics/msmarvel/ )

As a result, Carol’s words read like a plea to comics in general- ‘Grow. Mature. Stop your patriarchal bullshit and let’s try and act like something better than all that crap.’ It’s pretty impressive stuff, really- the default comics approach, even today, would be to retcon the story somehow, but Claremont deliberately leaves it to stand (although he does make a point of erasing any of the consequences by killing off the Marcus character and having Danvers reassert herself as here, in this reality, with her own plans, which at least gives her some degree of liberation from that ill thought out arc). This means that the actions of the so-called heroes have to be addressed, rather than being recast in a more favourable light.

Claremont makes a point of leaving them to face their faults: the heroes have let down one of their own, and don’t get a free pass. Comics creators let down one of their own, and they need to admit that. The Annual asks them to do better and not repeat those mistakes again.

It’s interesting to see that just as Captain Marvel now leads the charge for female-centred Marvel Studios product (and the ensuing complaints that prospect brings from the entitled and ignorant), she had tried to do the same for comics even before Kelly Sue gave her the Captain title she had long deserved and really put her on the map once more. Looks like it’s time to find those old Claremont Ms Marvels and see what else there is to admire in there.

From Avengers Annual 10, by Chris Claremont, Michael Golden, Armando Gil & Joe Rosen, reprinted in True Believers: Captain Marvel- Betrayed!

summary: i saw a post about the captain marvel movie that said “i hope this movie doesn’t encourage women to join the military” and....
body:
i saw a post about the captain marvel movie that said “i hope this movie doesn’t encourage women to join the military” and. like.

  • what about the captain america movies?
  • even if we say that ol’ cap inspired men to join the military more than he inspired women, isn’t that still equally as bad?
  • if it’s not equally as bad, then are you really anti-war, or do you just view men as more disposable than women?

reblog.comment:

summary: Where is my GOTG-Captain Marvel crossover?
title: Where is my GOTG-Captain Marvel crossover?
body:
I need

1) Teen Peter doing a dance battle with Carole.

2) Rocket and Groot meet Goose

3) AU where Carole and Meredith become lovers and raise Peter (F * ck Ego)

4) AU where Carole, Yondu and Talos kick some Kree ass together.

5) Goose fight Thanos and Win!

6) AU Where Carole, Maria and Meredith raise Peter and Monica together.

7) Carole save young Peter and become bro with Yondu. 

8) Carole save and adopte Mantis.

9) Insert here other awesome ideas
